comment: I like how she said "so yes is the answer" and then more and more people kept putting no

It seems some people are arriving at this video from a search rather than as part of the lecture series playlist. This is a supplementary video to a lecture. These links may come in handy to connect to the lecture this is based on.   Timestamps & description from Lei Xun 3. Testing approaches: natural boundaries for numbers, random testing, black box testing and glass box testing 7:45 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9H6muyZjms0&t=465s 4. Black box testing is based on specification, an example 9:05 5. Glass box testing tries to test every single path of the code 10:20
the path isn't complete cuz of the 0 cases haven't been covered since 0 is even and the method returns false for it!
Ah, no explanation for Glassbox and Blackbox testing. Thanks!
This is a good video series.
it still completes all 3 paths so,,,

@peasant7214  To add, the lecture this question is associated with specifically mentions  that path-complete tests can still miss bugs and that care should be taken to test boundary conditions as well.
